questions.text: During a neck dissection, a surgeon accidentally damages the hypoglossal nerve. Which neck triangle is likely being dissected?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: The agglutination test of a 2-day-old baby born to an Rh-negative mother is given below. The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of?
questions.solution:
The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of the D antigen. The given agglutination test shows agglutination only with the Rh antiserum. The Rh antigen in the given options is the D antigen.

From the given agglutination test, the blood group of the baby is O-positive, as there is agglutination with the Rh antiserum, but no agglutination with A or B antisera. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. 

In an Rh-positive individual, the presence of the D antigen is specific and carries antigenic properties responsible for hemolytic reactions. 

There are six common types of Rh antigens (C, D, E and c, d, e) each of which is called an Rh factor. The type D antigen is more antigenic than the others. Individuals who have the type D antigen are said to be Rh-positive, whereas those who don't have it are Rh-negative.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

 

Blood type Genotype

Agglutinogen

Agglutinins
A AA or OA A Anti-B
B BB or OB B Anti-A
O OO - Anti-A, Anti-B
AB AB A, B -

 

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. Absence of this H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

However, the O blood group has an H antigen. Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.  

Other less common systems of blood grouping include MNSs, Lutheran, Kell, and Kidd systems of blood grouping.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice (serum bilirubin levels over 20 mg/dL) and accompanying brain damage.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and coughing at night that awakens him from sleep. He is a known case of COPD. On examination, distended neck veins and S3 sounds were noted. The bronchoalveolar lavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages.

They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung.

The following image shows siderophages.

questions.text: A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with some difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils which bleeds on scraping the lesion.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is as shown below. What is the organism associated with the disease?
questions.solution:
The history of white membrane over the tonsils and gram stain image showing gram-positive bacilli in Chinese letter arrangement points towards the diagnosis of faucial diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Corynebacterium diphtheria is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called as polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding of the toxin to the cells and fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis, a bull neck, and severe toxemia. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils are characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria is due to non-toxigenic strains of diphtheria. It may present as a diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Isolation of corynebacterium from patient or close contact confirms the diagnosis. Specimen collection for culture should be done from nose, throat and if possible from below the membrane. It grows readily on Loeffler's serum slope and confirmation can be done by growing on potassium tellurite agar which serves as a selective medium.

Image below shows Loeffler's serum slope.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented to the clinic with difficulty in vision. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for which she has been on medication for many years along with drugs for the management of her diabetes and hypertension. Fundus examination of the patient shows the following finding. Which of the following drug could have caused this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the bull’s eye maculopathy which can be caused by hydroxychloroquine. This patient's history of being treated for rheumatoid arthritis is the most probable reason for the lesion.

Bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium, giving a "bulls-eye" appearance to the macula.

Hydroxychloroquine, which is generally used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, toxicity causes bull’s eye maculopathy. Chloroquine binds to melanin in the retinal pigment epithelium, causing cytotoxic effects.

Causes of bull’s eye maculopathy include:

  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Congenital cone dystrophy

Other adverse effects of chloroquine:

  • Nail bed and mucosal membrane discoloration
  • Irreversible retinopathy
  • Ototoxicity
  • Toxic myopathy
  • Cardiopathy
  • Peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: During the autopsy of a patient who died of suspected poisoning, it was noted that he had pink-coloured skin and mucosa. Prior to death, he had a bitter almond smell from his breath and frothy discharge.  What is the most likely cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards cyanide poisoning.

Poisoning by cyanide:

  • Cyanides are protoplasmic cytotoxic poisons.
  • They act by inhibiting cytochrome oxidases for utilising O2 in a cell, leading to internal asphyxia (cellular asphyxia), leading to death.
  • It can also act on other enzymes mildly.
  • It also acts as a corrosive on mucosa.
  • Inhalation brings about death instantaneously by respiratory arrest.

Clinical Features in small doses

  • Saltish taste in mouth
  • Smell of bitter almonds to the breath
  • Salivation, nausea, vomiting
  • Cyanosis

Clinical Features in large doses

  • Rapid loss of consciousness, convuslions, coma, death
  • Very often found deadat the scene 

Treatment of cyanide poisoning:

  • Nitrites (Amyl nitrite,Sodium nitrite) are given to convert haemoglobin to methaemoglobin.
  • Cyanides combine with methaemoglobin to form cyanmethaemoglobin , which in the presence of rhodonase & sodium thiosulphate converts cyanide to thiocyanate which is excreted in urine.

Other antidotes:

  • Hydroxycobalamin (vitamin B12)
  • Dicobalt EDTA
  • PAPP(Para amino propio phenol)
 

Hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate are the preferred antidotes in cyanide toxicity.

  • If hydroxocobalamin is available,  give hydroxocobalamin and sodium thiosulfate. 
  • If hydroxocobalamin is not available, give amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. Avoid nitrites if the patient has contraindications to nitrites.

Hydroxocobalamin is preferred over sodium nitrite as it does not interfere with the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. Also, sodium nitrite can induce fatal methemoglobinemia in patients who are critically ill from another cause.

Mechanism of action of antidotes:

Mechanism of antidote   Example
Binding of cyanide Direct binding of cyanide, followed by clearance Hydroxocobalamin
Induction of methemoglobinemia When cyanide binds methemoglobin, a relatively less toxic cyanomethemoglobin is formed

Sodium nitrite

Amyl nitrite
Use of sulfur donors This involves maximizing the availability of sulfur donors for rhodanese, a ubiquitous enzyme that detoxifies cyanide by transforming it to thiocyanate Sodium thiosulfate

Condition Colour of hypostasis

Carbon monoxide poisoning Bright cherry red
Cyanide poisoning Pink
Phosphorus poisoning Dark brown
Nitrate poisoning Reddish brown
Chlorate poisoning Chocolate brown
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning Bluish Green
Aniline poisoning Deep blue
Opiate poisoning Black

Other options:

Option A: Carbon monoxide poisoning shows the characteristic postmortem staining with bright cherry red discoloration.

Option C: Hydrogen sulphide poisoning shows characteristic blue-green staining.

Option D: Datura poisoning predominantly presents with peripheral anticholinergic effects like flushed face, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils, delirium, urinary retention, etc. with central effects like psychosis and delirium.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her mother with complaints of mouth breathing. She has a flat, expressionless, long face with an open mouth. On examination, a high-arched palate and crowded upper teeth are noted. The X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the x-ray which shows enlarged adenoids suggests the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The neovascularization arises from the optic nerve head; there is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) along the large vessels and neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins. These represent areas of nerve fiber infarcts. Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

Image shows cotton wool spots

questions.text: A 20 yr old man presents with fever and malaise for 4 days and a rash for the past 2 days. It was initially on his back, but then it appeared on his arms and legs too. On examination, he has a pleomorphic rash with areas of papules, vesicles, and a few crusts. Until when should the patient be isolated?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has chickenpox and needs to isolate himself until all the lesions are crusted, which takes approximately 6 days from onset of rash. Only symptomatic treatment is needed in this case. Acyclovir is recommended only if administered within 24 hours.

The period of infectivity is from ~48 h before the onset of the vesicular rash, during the period of vesicle formation that generally lasts 4–5 days, and until all vesicles are crusted.

questions.text: A 9 month old baby with diarrhoea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 4 seconds. What is the management?

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.solution:
According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has 'some dehydration' and comes under Plan B.

The treatment under Plan B for a 9 month old baby is:

400-700 ml of ORS at home to be given in the first four hours. In addition to this, 50-100 ml extra fluid is given after each loose stool.

After four hours, the baby is reassessed and the appropriate plan is selected again for the continuation of the treatment.

The four rules of home treatment are:

  • Give extra fluid.
  • Give zinc supplements (1 tablet per day for 14 days, dssolved in a smal amount of ORS, breast milk and clean water).
  • Continue breastfeeding.
  • Counsel the mother to return if there is blood in stools,and if the child is feeding poorly.

questions.text: You are a medical officer evaluating the community health meal programs in your area. One of the program's objectives is to attract more children to maintain attendance in school. Which one of the following statements about this meal program is correct?

choices.text: Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/2 of daily energy requirement and 1/3rd of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/4th of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/4th of daily protein requirement

questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the mid-day meal program is the meal should provide at least 1/3rd of the daily energy requirement and 1/2 of the daily protein requirement. 

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the Ministry of Education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meals should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of Human Resources Development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman from Sweden comes to the hospital complaining of blurry vision from the past 3 days. Her symptoms are aggravated when she takes a hot shower. She also complains of an electric shock-like sensation radiating down her spine into her legs. This is the first time that such an attack has happened. Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of the first attack of this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Glucocorticoids are used in the clinical management of either first attacks or acute exacerbations.

Intravenous methylprednisolone administration at a dose of 500–1000 mg/day for 3-5 days, followed by a course of oral prednisolone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/day and gradually tapered over 2 weeks is given.

These medications reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks.

Some of the disease-modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are:

  •  IFN-β-1a (Avonex)
  • IFN-β-1a (Rebif)
  • Glatiramer acetate 
  • Natalizumab

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent fetal losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions all at <10 weeks of gestational age, and has a history of deep vein thrombosis. There is no history of SLE.  Which of the following antibodies are not useful in making a diagnosis in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of >3 spontaneous abortions at <10 weeks of gestational age along with a history of deep vein thrombosis suggests a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome. Anti beta-2 microglobulin is not useful in the diagnosis of this condition.

For the diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome, high titers of one or more of the following three should be demonstrated along with at least one clinical symptom of thrombosis or pregnancy complications.

  • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - most specific
  • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies - most sensitive
  • Anti-beta-2 glycoprotein 1 antibodies

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The gross specimen image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of the cystoprostatectomy specimen shows a large, fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder with the two lobes of the prostate not being much affected. The most likely diagnosis is bladder carcinoma. 

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma is divided into 3 groups:

  • Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. It accounts for 70% of cases.
  • Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis and staging are done by cystoscopy and resection of the tumor. A bimanual examination should be performed after the resection of the tumor. Complete urinary tract imaging is required using contrast computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance (MR) urography.

Management:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options: 

Option A- Leukoplakia is squamous metaplasia of the bladder characterized by white particles (keratin) in the urine. Diffuse leukoplakia of the bladder is pre-malignant and can lead to squamous cancer of the bladder. It has to be assessed by cystoscopy and localized areas may be resected.

Option C- Prostate carcinoma presents with symptoms only during advanced disease. It causes bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, and renal failure. It is surgically managed by radical prostatectomy, which only involves the removal of the prostate and seminal vesicles and preserving the bladder. Unlike the given gross specimen one or more lobes are predominantly involved in prostatic carcinoma.

Option D- Schistosomiasis of the bladder is a parasitic infection by Schistosoma haematobium. Cystoscopy would show nodules, pseudotubercles, ulceration, or sandy patches. Chronic infection can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.

 

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Cigarette smoking
Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-
naphthylamine and related compounds (e.g., in diesel exhaust, in paint products)
Schistosoma haematobium infestation
Long-term use of analgesics (phenacetin)
Heavy-dose long-term use of cyclophosphamide
Radiotherapy
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Heriditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations in FGFR3, HRAS, P53, RB genes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency after being trapped in a landslide for 3-4 hours. He has multiple rib fractures, pneumothorax, hemothorax, and lab findings of elevated creatinine, creatine phosphokinase, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of prolonged entrapment, clinical features, and laboratory findings are all suggestive of crush syndrome. 

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Clinical features:

  • The affected limb is pulseless, red, and swollen
  • In some cases, sensation and muscle power may be lost.

Management of crush syndrome

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure.
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed.
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis.
  • Aggressive management of the open wound.

Other options:

Option A: Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after a fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. It is usually seen 2-3 days following the injury. Clinical features include tachycardia, rise in temperature, breathlessness, and mild mental confusion. 

Option C: Hemorrhagic shock is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Option D: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures(commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intracompartmental pressures.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy leading to a bile leak. 

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of the entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 Option A: Infection is very unlikely to present in the immediate postoperative period with a pus collection of 5x5cms particularly after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option B: Surgical site pain will not be severe and diffuse instead it is localized and bearable.

Option D: Retained gallstones are very unlikely.

questions.text: A young male patient, with a history of blunt abdominal trauma, was brought to the ER. As he was hemodynamically unstable, and FAST examination revealed free fluid, an immediate laparotomy was done. Since severe bleeding from the liver was present, the following manoeuvre was done to visualize the injury but, the bleeding continued even after clamping. What could be the probable source of bleeding in this case?

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.solution:
The image shows clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in Pringle maneuver and bleeding from hepatic vein will continue even after clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament.

Pringle maneuver:

  • When severe bleeding from the liver is present, the Pringle maneuver is a valuable adjunct to slow blood flow enough to visualize the injury.
  • The hepatoduodenal ligament is encircled with a vessel loop or vascular clamp to occlude hepatic blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein.
  • This maneuver helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding, which will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped.
  • In many cases, the liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.
  • Hepatic parenchyma that appears to be devitalized should be debrided and drains should be placed when injuries appear to be at risk for a bile leak.
  • A vascularized pedicle of the omentum may reduce parenchymal bleeding and promote healing of the laceration when it is packed with the liver injury.

questions.text: A P5 female bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate IV fluids with oxytocin.  However, the patient continues to bleed over the next 10 min even after adequate uterine massage. On examination,  she is tachycardic, hypotensive and the uterus is soft and boggy.  What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management is to carry out balloon tamponade.

  • When the uterine bleeding is unresponsive to uterotonic agents, bimanual uterine compression can be performed, IV lines must be placed and volume resuscitation started.
  • A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity. 

Other options mentioned are surgical methods of management. These are tried after all forms of medical management have failed.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advise regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B - CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C - Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in?
questions.solution:
Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths (as shown in the image below). Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition.

Genital warts:

Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. They are most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

 

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as a crop of small domed vesicles with central umbilication. It is caused by the pox virus and it spreads by close sexual or nonsexual contact and by autoinoculation.

Option C: Chancroid appears as small papules that develop into painful ulcerating pustules. They are associated with unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is caused by H. ducreyi.

Option D: Herpes appears as multiple crops of vesicles and ulcers.

questions.text: You are a resident observing an intern resuscitate a newborn in the labor room. After half a minute of bag and mask ventilation by the intern, the infant is still pale and hypoxic. What would you advise the intern?

choices.text: Readjust the mask and head position

questions.solution:
The next step in this newborn with ineffective bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is to readjust the mask and reposition the head.

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) by BMV is given when infants fail to breathe at birth. The infant's neck is slightly extended to make sure the airway is open. The care provider is at the head end of the baby and a face mask of appropriate size is chosen to cover the mouth and nose. The adequacy of ventilation is indicated by visible chest rise and when normal chest rise is observed, ventilation should be started.

Increasing heart rate; spontaneous respiration; and improvement in color, saturation, and tone help to assess the infant's improvement.

When there is no improvement after 30 seconds of BMV(according to Nelson's textbook of pediatrics) or 15 seconds of BMV (according to the Indian Association of Pediatrics), ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows - MRSOPA

  • Mask has to be reapplied 
  • Reposition the infant's head
  • Suction the secretions
  • Open the mouth
  • Increase the Pressure
  • Use an Alternative airway.

questions.text: The following anomaly is seen in :
questions.solution:
The above picture depicts Starfish hand and is seen in Achondroplasia.

In these patients, middle finger is shorter than usual resulting in all digits being of equal length (starfish hand). There is separation between middle and ring fingers described as Trident hand.

Other features:

  • Most common form of disproportionate dwarfism.
  • Inheritance is autosomal dominant
  • Usually normal intelligence and sexual development
  • Hands are short and broad
  • Posterior scalloping of vertebrae

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic requesting liposuction. She feels she is obese and would like to get rid of the "excess fat". On further enquiry, she reveals a habit of eating high-calorie food multiple times a month which she later regrets and skipping meals at times. Her BMI is 23. An examination of her hands is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows calluses and pigmentation on knuckles, known as Russell's sign. The given clinical history of binge eating, body-image issues, Russell's sign along with a normal BMI is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. The calluses on hands form due to the repeated scraping of knuckles on the teeth, during self-induced vomiting. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

Treatment of bulimia nervosa:

  • Without comorbid mood disorders - fluoxetine, topiramate, CBT
  • With comorbid mood disorders - carbamazepine

questions.text: A known cardiac patient who underwent PCI with stent placement 6 months ago is on regular aspirin ever since. He is posted for emergency hernia surgery for the strangulated hernia. What would be your advice regarding aspirin?

choices.text: Stop aspirin and replace with heparin
Stop aspirin and give platelet transfusion

questions.solution:
If a patient on a coronary stent taking aspirin is posted for surgery, aspirin should be continued even on the day of surgery to avoid the risk of stent rethrombosis, myocardial infarction or death.

Antiplatelet drugs should not be interrupted in patients with coronary stents without consultation with a cardiologist.

  • Drug-eluting coronary stents require antiplatelet administration for at least 6 months.
  • Bare metal stents for at least one month.

Ideally, elective surgery is avoided for one month in patients with bare coronary stents and one year for those with drug-eluting stents. But emergency surgeries cannot be postponed.

Note: The drug-eluting stents delay this endothelial growth by eluting drugs like sirolimus/paclitaxel etc and thereby reduce the risk of endothelial overgrowth causing occlusion. But this prolonged lack of endothelial lining causes an increased risk of thrombosis and hence a longer duration of antiplatelet therapy is required with drug-eluting stents.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pruritic hypopigmented macules and confluent patches over the chest as seen in the image. Which of the following color would you expect on Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pruritic lesion over the trunk and image showing sharply demarcated multiple hypopigmented macules and coalescing into patches with fine scales is suggestive of pityriasis versicolor or tinea versicolor. On Wood's lamp examination these lesions show pale yellow fluorescence. 

Wood's lamp is a source of ultraviolet rays. All visible rays from this source are excluded by Wood's filter. In fungal infections like pityriasis versicolor, it shows the pale yellow fluorescence as given below.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species competitively inhibits tyrosinase and results in hypopigmentation.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’. 

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Relapse is very common. 

Other options:

Option A- Coral pink fluorescence is seen in erythrasma.

Option B- Red fluorescence is seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

Option D- Green fluorescence is seen in tinea capitis infections associated with Microspora species and favus.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's Lamp Examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp. Black light is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: blue-green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum); 

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue.

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

 

Erythrasma

Coral pink

questions.text: An 18-month-child is brought to the pediatrician with the history of distension of abdomen and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and radiograph of the child is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly and cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler Syndrome.

Hurler syndrome is also known as MPS 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Phenotypical features of Hurler's syndrome and Hunter's syndrome are quite similar; however, Hunter syndrome (deficiency of iduronate sulfatase enzyme) is generally less severe than Hurler syndrome and can be clinically differentiated by a lack of corneal clouding.

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTIs is suspected to have a congenital renal anomaly. The following picture is seen on IV urography. Based on these findings, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a right-sided fish hook or S-shaped ureter. It describes the appearance of a retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC.

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. There is a persistent right posterior cardinal vein that ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

Note: Bilateral fishhook or J-shaped or hockey stick ureters describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).
